title: Johanna Jacoba van Beaumont
text:
Johanna Jacoba van Beaumont (c. 1752, <a href="Sluis">Sluis</a>17 October 1827, <a href="Bergen%20op%20Zoom">Bergen op Zoom</a>), was a politically active <a href="Dutch%20people">Dutch</a> <a href="journalist">journalist</a>, <a href="Feminism">feminist</a> and <a href="Editing">editor</a>. 
She belonged to the radical <a href="Democrats%2066">democrats</a> who were active in the radical paper "Nationaale Bataafsche Courant" after the <a href="Batavian%20Revolution">Batavian Revolution</a> of 1795. In 1797, she organised a list of names which she delivered to the national <a href="States%20General%20of%20the%20Netherlands">parliament</a> in support of a radically democratic <a href="constitution">constitution</a> wherein she suggested women should be willing to fight to the death for a democratically centralized system. She signed with the name "Catharina" which led to her colleague <a href="Catharina%20Heybeek">Catharina Heybeek</a> being arrested in 1798 for incitement in the place of Johanna.
